human: One of the ambition of the people is to create a harmonious community to live in. Unfortunately, individuals often fail to create one. This essay will discuss what is an ideal society, as well as ways on how to make it happen.An ideal community is a place where peace of mind over shadows fear. We all now that everyone wants a place that is criminal free. For example, people can just walk in an aisle without thinking of being raped or kidnapped. Moreover, it is a community in which discrimination, prejudice and racism is prohibited. In short, everyone is treated equally regardless of gender, colors, religions, social status, jobs and looks. It also means that, people can just walk in and out of a hospital or establishments without being looked down or degraded by other people especially those with high status.However, it is difficult for people to meet this kind of standards. This mainly because nobody is made perfect and as a human being we are mostly dominated by hatred, jealousy and selfishness. Although people fail to have a perfect society, there are some ways on how to have a near perfect place to live. First of all, government should make the lives of the people a better one by being an active role model to the citizens. There should not be corruption involve amongst the higher ups. Also, as what the saying goes "learning should start at home", it means that, parents should the take the initiative to educate their children proper manners in dealing with other people. In Japan, children were taught in a very young age on how to treat other people. That is why they always bow down their head as a sign of respect.To conclude, creating an essential environment can be challenging and demanding for all of us. Eventhough, it is impossible to make, each one of us can has the capacity to contribute to make society an almost perfect one.
llm: The notion of a perfect society has captivated the minds of philosophers, activists, and everyday people for centuries. Typically, an ideal society is defined by its commitment to fairness, equality, peace, and a high standard of living for all its citizens. Nevertheless, the pursuit of such a society remains a challenge due to the complexities of human nature, diverse values, and socioeconomic systems.From my perspective, an ideal society is one that provides equal access to education, healthcare, and employment opportunities, regardless of an individual's background. In this type of society, diversity is valued, and the rights of all individuals are protected. For example, countries like those in Scandinavia exhibit characteristics of an ideal society, with their comprehensive welfare systems, low corruption rates, and strong social bonds. These nations prioritize investments in education and public services, resulting in higher living standards and greater citizen satisfaction.To create an ideal society, a multifaceted approach is necessary. Firstly, education is essential, as it fosters critical thinking and empathy from a young age, enabling individuals to appreciate diverse viewpoints and work collaboratively towards common objectives. Moreover, raising awareness about social issues and promoting civic engagement can empower citizens to take an active role in shaping their communities.Furthermore, policymakers must prioritize policies that promote inclusivity and equity. Implementing universal basic rights, such as accessible healthcare and education, can reduce inequality and ensure that every individual has the necessary resources to thrive. Countries that have implemented progressive taxation and social safety nets demonstrate how thoughtful governance can lead to a more equitable society.Lastly, cultivating a culture of dialogue and understanding can help bridge societal divides. Community-led initiatives that bring together different demographic groups for meaningful conversations can address misconceptions and foster solidarity among citizens.In conclusion, although the idea of an ideal society may seem like a distant dream, incremental steps - rooted in education, inclusive policies, and open dialogue - can significantly enhance societal well-being and bring us closer to realizing this aspiration.

question: People should follow the local customs and traditions, when they come to live in a new country. To what extent do you agree or disagree?
human: The globalised world these days makes it simpler than ever before for people to relocate and start building a life in a new country. As everyone comes from their own cultural background, a question arises of whether or not people should be expected to follow the customs of their host country. I completely agree with the view that while learning about the local customs may require some time and effort, it is valuable and will aid the integration of the newcomers into society.In many cultures following the local customs means showing respect, which is an important moral value in nearly every culture. The opposite is also true: disregarding traditions is often seen as a sign of disrespect. In order to establish good neighbourly relationships and feel welcome in the new place, it is important to demonstrate the effort to become part of the community. By expressing an interest in learning traditions, new arrivals gain a chance to interact with their neighbours and colleagues, get to know them and build some connections in the new country.Another positive aspect is the enhanced feeling of belonging that people get from participating in activities others around them are doing. When a national festival is in full swing, standing on the sidelines might make people feel excluded and perhaps even homesick, whereas joining others opens up opportunities to attend special events together, go to parties, meet new people and feel part of the celebrations. In Australia, for example, Easter is a very special time of the year and some of the traditional activities include Easter egg decoration and gifting, and baking hot cross buns; sharing your designs and recipes with others is an excellent conversation starter.In conclusion, learning the customs and traditions of one’s new country doesn’t mean a loss of their own culture. On the contrary, it is an opportunity to gain a deeper understanding of cultural connections and should be embraced as a positive experience.
llm: When relocating to a foreign country, assimilating into local customs and traditions is frequently regarded as the key to successful integration. I firmly believe that adopting these cultural norms can greatly enhance an expat's experience and facilitate their assimilation into the community, while also acknowledging the importance of nuanced considerations.Embracing local customs plays a vital role in fostering reciprocal respect and comprehension between newcomers and long-time residents. By dedicating time to learning about and participating in local customs, immigrants demonstrate a willingness to engage with and connect to the surrounding culture. For example, participating in local celebrations, grasping social etiquette, or even acquiring the local language can establish connections between disparate communities, potentially leading to enduring friendships and a sense of belonging.Furthermore, comprehending and adhering to local customs is essential for navigating everyday situations, whether in social or professional environments. It enhances one's understanding of societal norms and legal frameworks, which is vital for harmonious coexistence in a new environment. Misconceptions stemming from cultural disparities can frequently lead to isolation or conflict, rendering knowledge of local customs indispensable.Nonetheless, this viewpoint does not advocate for the total relinquishment of one's cultural identity. Rather, a balance should be achieved, wherein immigrants can proudly observe their heritage while also engaging with the customs of their host nation. This cross-cultural exchange can augment the local culture, promote diversity, and contribute to a more inclusive society.Ultimately, embracing local customs and traditions is vital for newcomers, yet it is equally crucial to preserve their cultural heritage. This synergy not only enriches the individual's experience but also contributes to the cultural diversity of the society as a whole. By embracing cultural diversity through reciprocal respect and comprehension, a more cohesive and harmonious community can be fostered.

question: People should not work beyond the retirement age (agree/disagree)
human: Some believe that people should not continue to work once they reach the age of retirement. Do you agree or disagree? Give reasons for your answer and include relevant examples from your experience.In recent years, with the improvement in healthcare sector and better , people are able to live longer and contribute to the economic progress of a nation more, compared to the past. Some see this as an entirely positive development, while others point out the drawbacks of working beyond the retirement age.Delaying retirement enables individuals to actively contribute to the society. On a personal level, working past retirement age provides an avenue for individuals to remain not only physically but also mentally active. Moreover, this option empowers the ageing population to be financially independent and economically self-sustainable past retirement age. In countries with growing ageing population such as Singapore, for instance, citizens are given an option to work beyond their retirement age based on the demands of their job and their capability to handle these tasks. Hence, working beyond retirement age empowers workers, ensures economic progression of the nation, and alleviates the challenges faced by an ageing population.On the flip side, working beyond the retirement age may result in adverse health impacts on workers and a decrease in productivity levels. In Japan, the suicide rates have recently been increasing due to rising stress levels at work faced by the ageing population who are pushed to work beyond their optimal capacity. Escalating stress levels from work to various health complications putting a strain on the healthcare system. Hence, working beyond retirement age may worsen the overall welfare of individuals and adversely impact the economy.To sum up, though working beyond retirement age health hazards leading to reduction in productivity levels, it seems to me that the benefits far outweigh the disadvantages. In my opinion, by assessing the capability of individuals and tailoring their jobs to their health profile, firms and companies should actively involve their workers to be productive beyond their retirement age.This essay is an excellent example of IELTS Band 8 writing. The author presents sound arguments making his/her point of view very clear, examples are being used to support the writer’s points and the organisation of information is handled very well. There are some minor inaccuracies, however, they wouldn’t affect the score much in the real test. Well done!
llm: The debate surrounding the issue of whether individuals should continue working beyond their retirement age is highly contentious, with various viewpoints emerging that take into account economic, social, and personal considerations. Although some people argue in favor of working past retirement age, I firmly believe that individuals should not feel obligated to continue working beyond this significant life milestone.Primarily, retirement is not merely the cessation of work, but rather a distinct phase of life focused on relaxation, personal pursuits, and family time. Following decades of diligent work, individuals have earned the right to indulge in leisure activities, pursue hobbies, travel, or engage in volunteer work. For many, this transition represents a well-deserved shift from a life dominated by work to one that prioritizes personal fulfillment and enjoyment. Continuing to work beyond retirement age can reduce the opportunity for individuals to fully capitalize on this crucial life phase.Furthermore, the physical and mental health consequences of working beyond retirement age are significant and cannot be ignored. Older adults may encounter health challenges that render full-time employment challenging, and in some instances, harmful. Prolonged work can exacerbate stress, leading to burnout, and negatively impact both physical and mental well-being. Fostering a culture that pressures elderly individuals to continue working can ultimately contribute to a decline in their overall quality of life.In addition, there are notable economic implications to consider. If older individuals remain in the workforce for extended periods, it can limit job opportunities for younger generations, potentially leading to higher unemployment rates among youth and stagnation in career progression for those newly entering the labor market. Encouraging older adults to retire and create space for younger employees not only promotes a diverse workforce but also facilitates the transfer of knowledge from seasoned professionals to newcomers.In conclusion, while the decision to work beyond retirement age is ultimately a personal choice, societal norms should promote the idea that retirement should be a time for rest, relaxation, and rejuvenation. Society benefits when older generations can enjoy their post-work years, free from the burdens of employment, allowing younger generations to step forward and contribute dynamically to the workforce.

question: People think that the best way to reduce crime is to give longer prison sentences. Others believe that there are other alternative solutions for reducing crime.Discuss both views and give your opinion on this topic.
human: Nowadays the sentences that judges give to criminals is always at the centre of attention of the society; some people think that the best way to reduce the amount of crime cases is to give longer prison sentences, while, others say that there are other alternative ways to stop it. This essay will talk about both views and, at the end, I will give my opinion about the argument.It is always more common to see long sentences for criminals, also if their crimes are not too bad to deserve that type of punishment; the reason why the court gives to them long sentences is because they think that staying a lot in prison will make the criminals understand that what they did is wrong and, next time, they will think twice before doing something bad or against the law.However long sentences can go against the human rights because they will take away from prisoners years of their life; for this reason, some people think that it can be better if, instead of stay close in a jail without doing nothing, they can be used in various works that will make them useful for the society and better person at the end of the sentence, like cleaning the city, helping old people in retirement homes and also cook for poor people.I think that there are other ways to stop crime instead of giving long punishments, also because everyone should have a second chance in their life and, more importantly, teach and show to prisoners different aspects of the community will help cities to become better places with less crimes to stop.This essay talked about two different types of views about crime sentences in our society, with my own opinion about the argument in the last part of it.
llm: The topic of crime reduction has generated significant discussion, with some people advocating for longer prison sentences as a primary means of deterrence, while others propose alternative approaches. Both viewpoints present valid arguments worthy of consideration.On one hand, proponents of longer prison sentences believe that harsher penalties can effectively deter criminal behavior. They argue that the fear of severe punishment can prevent individuals from engaging in illicit activities. Additionally, longer sentences keep dangerous offenders out of society for extended periods, which could reduce the likelihood of recidivism upon release. This perspective is supported by data indicating that certain crimes have declined in areas with strict sentencing laws.On the other hand, those who favor alternative methods contend that merely increasing prison sentences does not address the underlying causes of crime. Many offenders come from disadvantaged backgrounds marked by poverty, lack of education, and mental health problems. Consequently, investing in community programs, education, job training, and mental health services could lead to more substantial long-term benefits. They argue that rehabilitation, rather than punishment alone, can facilitate successful reintegration into society, reduce recidivism rates, and have a more profound impact on society as a whole.In my view, a balanced approach might be the most effective way to reduce crime. While longer prison sentences may be suitable for serious offenses, incorporating alternative solutions is essential for addressing the root causes of criminality. By providing support and rehabilitation for offenders, society can create an environment where individuals can successfully reintegrate, breaking the cycle of crime. In conclusion, although stringent sentencing may serve as a deterrent, a multifaceted strategy that combines punishment with rehabilitation is likely to lead to more sustainable crime reduction.

question: People today find their lives more and more dominated by their jobs. To what extent do you agree or disagree with this statement?Give reasons for your answer and include any relevant examples from your knowledge or experience.You should write at least 250 words.
human: It is certainly true that many people around the world find their lives dominated by the work that they have to do. This is shown when you realise how people’s work, and how much time, effort and resources they devote to it, is often the subject of conversation.Most people depend on their jobs to generate an income to pay for their lives’ necessities and luxuries, and so work can naturally become a dominating focus. As this is an important part of nearly everyone’s everyday life, it can seem that people’s lives are indeed becoming more influenced by their jobs. Whether this emphasis on work is more significant now than in previous years is debatable. In many developed countries around the world, there are procedures in place to help people with finding work, providing unemployment benefits, ensuring education, and offering pension payments. In times past, these provisions were not in place and a job or business was required to provide the necessary income.Therefore, in spite of increases in the cost of living in many places around the world, it can be argued there is actually less pressure than in previous years to keep one’s job and perform well at it. This, in turn, would lead to people’s lives being less influenced by their jobs today. It is also true that in the past, people were as responsible and focused on doing well in their responsibilities as today and so, in this respect, the people of the past would be equally dedicated to their work as people are today.While I agree that people’s lives today are often dominated by their jobs, I feel that the current situation is not necessarily worse than before. In fact, it may be more positive, due to the fewer pressures to earn money in many countries.
llm: The pervasive presence of work in modern society has led to a profound change in how people experience and prioritize their lives. The notion that individuals' lives are becoming increasingly dominated by their jobs is one that I largely support, and it is driven by factors such as technological advancements, cultural norms, and economic pressures.The impact of technology is a primary factor in this shift. The rise of smartphones and remote work capabilities has erased the boundaries between professional and personal life, making employees accessible 24/7. This has created an expectation to be constantly available, responding to work-related messages and emails outside of work hours, which can lead to a sense of perpetual obligation that encroaches on personal time. A 2022 Gallup survey found that 53% of American employees reported being "always on," resulting in a heightened risk of burnout and stress.Societal norms also play a significant role in perpetuating this phenomenon. In many cultures, a person's value is often tied to their career achievements, fostering an environment where individuals feel pressured to prioritize their jobs over personal relationships and self-care. For instance, in highly competitive fields like finance or technology, long working hours are often glorified, and employees may feel compelled to conform to these demanding standards, sacrificing their well-being in the process.Economic factors are another crucial aspect that cannot be ignored. The rising cost of living in many areas has forced individuals to work longer hours or take on multiple jobs to make ends meet, leading to diminished leisure time and exacerbating feelings of job-related stress and dissatisfaction.In conclusion, while work is a vital aspect of life, it is clear that many individuals today find their lives heavily influenced, if not dominated, by their jobs. The interplay of technology, societal expectations, and economic realities contributes to a work-centric lifestyle that can often compromise personal well-being and happiness. It is essential for individuals and organizations to strive for a better balance, ensuring that work enhances, rather than overshadows, the richness and quality of life.

question: Percentage of UK people who consumed daily recommended amount of fruit and vegetable in 2002, 2006 and 2010.Summarize the information by selecting and reporting the main features and make comparisons where relevant.
human: The bar graph compares the proportion of UK citizens in terms of their consumption of daily recommended portions of fruits and vegetables in three different years which are 2002, 2006, and 2010.Overall, females consumed the highest percentage of their recommended healthy food, followed by males, and last are the children.additionally the year 2006 had witnessed the vastest consumption of vegetables and fruits among all given years.Women ate exactly 25% of the daily adviced dose of natural food in the year 2002, 32% in 2006, and 26% in 2010, however men took 22% of the recommended dose in the year 2002, 26% in 2006, and 24% in 2010.On the other hand younger individuals only consumed 11%, 18%, and 16% of the daily requirements of veggies and fruits in the years 2002, 2006, and 2010 respectively. It appears that residents of the UK had eaten the highest daily requirements of greens and fruits in the year 2006 as compared to the years 2006 and 2010.
llm: The dietary health of a population can be evaluated by monitoring the consumption of fruits and vegetables, which is a crucial indicator of nutritional well-being. In the UK, statistics show that the proportion of individuals consuming the recommended daily intake of five portions of fruits and vegetables has fluctuated over the years, specifically in 2002, 2006, and 2010.Back in 2002, a mere 24% of the UK population met the daily recommended intake, exposing a significant gap in nutritional standards. This low percentage suggests that, at the time, there was a lack of awareness about the importance of fresh produce or limited access to it. However, a notable improvement was observed by 2006, with the percentage increasing to 29%. This rise may be attributed to the impact of health campaigns and government initiatives that promoted healthier eating habits and emphasized the vital role of fruits and vegetables in a balanced diet.By 2010, the percentage had risen further to 33%, marking a significant upward trend from 2006. This increase may indicate a growing awareness among the population about the importance of fruits and vegetables in preventing chronic diseases and maintaining overall health. Other factors, such as improved food availability, public health advice, and shifting consumer preferences towards healthier options, may have also contributed to this rise.In conclusion, the period between 2002 and 2010 saw a steady increase in the proportion of UK residents meeting the recommended daily intake of fruits and vegetables, from 24% to 33%. This improvement signals a positive shift in dietary habits and a growing public commitment to nutrition. Nevertheless, despite the progress made, the statistics still reveal that a substantial portion of the population fails to meet the recommended intake, highlighting the ongoing need for public health education and initiatives in the UK to address this issue.

question: Popular events like the football world cup and other international sporting occasions are essential in easing international tensions and releasing patriotic emotions in a safe way. To what extent do you agree or disagree with this opinion?
human: The World Cup football and the Olympics are held worldwide with great national support and expectations. As a fan of those competitions, I agree with the idea that sporting events can be necessary for international relations and national unity, but only partially, because such events can have unintended effects on relationships between countries.First of all, the World Cup, Olympics and other international games work for easing tensions among different nations. For example, South and North Korea have football games regularly two nations a chance to understand each other . In the mid of North Korean supporters came to South Korea with the footballers and they were very excited during the sporting events. Even if it sounds ridiculous, many South Koreans were quite surprised at that moment when North Koreans shouted and cried during the match. We all realized that they were very normal sports fans even though they were occasionally very secretive. Through the sports, two divided nations could reduce their political and ideological tensions and could feel the patriotic unity.On the other hand, some sports matches can make international relations worse. For instance, football or baseball games between Korea and Japan are always big matches in two countries where . Sometimes, after the matches, the two rivals blame each other and their patriotic emotions explode in an aggressive way. scenario is that the troubles caused by losing games affect the players directly.
llm: Global sporting events, such as the Olympics and the Football World Cup, have a profound impact on promoting unity, reducing international tensions, and providing a controlled outlet for patriotic emotions. Although some argue that sports can fuel conflict, I strongly believe that the benefits of these events far outweigh the drawbacks.The primary advantage of international sporting events is that they offer a platform for nations to engage in friendly competition, fostering cultural exchange and dialogue among countries with differing political perspectives. Athletes serve as ambassadors for their nations, showcasing their skills, culture, and values. This exchange helps break down barriers and promotes mutual respect, as exemplified by the 1998 Football World Cup match between the United States and Iran, two nations often at odds with each other. Such moments remind us of our shared humanity and help bridge the gaps that exist in politics.Furthermore, these events provide citizens with a constructive outlet to express their national pride. When fans cheer for their teams, they channel their patriotism into supportive enthusiasm rather than hostility. This collective excitement unites diverse populations within countries, fostering a sense of community and shared identity. International sporting events thus serve as a healthy release for patriotic fervor, allowing individuals to celebrate their national identity in a peaceful and joyful context.While it is true that sports can sometimes intensify rivalries and lead to fan violence, this aspect should not be ignored. However, the safety measures and sportsmanship initiatives implemented by organizing committees significantly mitigate these risks. In conclusion, international sporting events, such as the Football World Cup, play a vital role in easing international tensions and providing a safe outlet for patriotic expressions. They offer opportunities for cultural exchange, collaboration, and national pride, ultimately promoting peace, unity, and global understanding.

question: Present a written argument or case to an educated non-specialist audience on the following topic:In the past, sporting champions used to be motivated primarily by the desire to win a match or to break world records. These days they are more likely to be motivated by prize money and the opportunity to be famous.What message does this send to young people and how does this attitude to sport affect the sports themselves?Give reasons for your answer and include any relevant examples from your own knowledge or experience.
human: There were many sport competitions organized after the World-War II since the first Olympic games was held in Athena, in 1963, to bring the world together again. Previously, sport competition was seen as an opportunity for the athletes to break the world records for the pride of their home countries. However, nowadays, people are more inclined to win the match because of money reward and glory. I believe that young people should be more encouraged to achieve their goals to become a champion so that the value of sport competition would not be purely for commercial purpose.In the last decades, there have been a lot of sport competitions being held from national to global level. The athletes were trained by the supported teams to do their best to become the world champion. It was the pride of such athlete to win and see their national flags were rised after the match. Over the years, sport has become more commercial following its popularity to attract global audiences. Many athletes are paying more attention for the opportunity to win the match for commercial purpose. For example, one wants to become a famous soccer player so that they could become the ambassador of Adidas and get more income out of it.Due to the temptation for getting famous and having more money, there are people who choose to play unfairly during a competition. Instead of focusing on increasing their skills, they would cheat to win the game for money. For example, a soccer player may use thyroid injection for boosting their energy level even though it is strictly prohibited. Moreover, sport is not seen anymore to promote peace and solidarity among people from different cultural backgrounds but for the chance to get the superficial gloriness.To conclude, even if the motivation has shifted, the young people should learn to focus more on becoming a real champion and play fairly so that they can become the best athletes in thier expertise while the money and glory would follow them after.
llm: The world of sports has undergone a profound transformation over the years, causing a significant shift in the motivations of many top athletes. Rather than being driven by an innate desire to succeed or break records, they are now often motivated by external factors such as financial rewards and fame. This change raises important questions about the impact on sports and the messages being conveyed to younger generations.Historically, athletes like Michael Jordan and Serena Williams were admired not only for their achievements, but also for their tireless work ethic, dedication, and pursuit of excellence. They personified the true essence of sports, demonstrating that success stems from passion and commitment. However, the current narrative has changed, with substantial prize money and lucrative sponsorship deals now drawing young athletes to sports not solely for the love of the game, but also for the prospect of financial gain and celebrity status. This transformation conveys a conflicting message to aspiring athletes, implying that success is equivalent to wealth and fame rather than perseverance and personal development.Furthermore, the emphasis on financial gain can lead to the commercialization of sports, where the true essence of competition becomes diluted, and superficial accomplishments are prioritized over genuine talent and hard work. For example, doping scandals in sports can often be attributed to athletes attempting to maintain or enhance their market value in an environment that only rewards visible successes.On the other hand, emphasizing the intrinsic values of sports, such as teamwork, discipline, and a genuine love for the game, can motivate young athletes to pursue their aspirations for the right reasons. Encouraging young individuals to appreciate the journey and the character-building aspects of athleticism can help foster a more positive and wholesome sporting culture.In conclusion, while the financial rewards of modern sports can be a powerful motivator, it is essential for coaches, parents, and mentors to instill values that respect the true essence of competition. By striking a balance between the realities of success and the fundamental joys of sports, we can nurture future champions who are not only successful, but also principled and grounded in their values.

question: Present a written argument or case to an educated non-specialist audience on the following topic:Some employers reward members of staff for their exceptional contribution to the company by giving them extra money. This practice can act as an incentive for some but may also have a negative impact on others.To what extent is this style of management effective?Are there better ways of encouraging employees to work hard?Give reasons for your answer and include any relevant examples from your own knowledge or experience.
human: Running a company and controlling their staff is a big responsibility for employers . In general, employers should have a great vision about the future of their own company and how to improve it in a better way .To start with, some employers reward members of staff for their exceptional contribution to the company by simply giving them more many. In addition, that practice can act as a good source of motivation, you can see that your hard work and your extra hours wasn't waste after all .On the other hand, this style of management may affect tha company and their community in a negative way . For example, the manager of the institution may be more focused on just one employee who's always have the extra credit for the work therefore the other employees work hard for nothing and that leave a bad idea that they clearly work for just having that extra money and rewards from the manager .Beside that, employees will be affected and their productivity will change and drop even more and all of that is a result on how the management of a company impact their work and their effort of doing more .To sum it up, all the members in that company worked so hard, a little credit for their effort and long hours of developing their company and rewards them for it won't do any harm . Not to mention, a manager can reward the staff of the institution by giving them a day or two off or basically a three hours break . Anything that make them really satisfied after their long and efficient work towards the developing of the company.
llm: In today's workplace, exceptional employee performance is often recognized through financial rewards. Although this approach can motivate some employees, it also risks creating inequality and dissatisfaction among staff members. This essay examines the effectiveness of financial rewards as a management tool and discusses alternative motivational methods.On the one hand, financial incentives can boost employee performance. When employees see a direct link between their efforts and financial gain, they are often motivated to exceed their usual responsibilities. For example, commission-based structures in sales roles can lead to increased productivity, as employees strive to meet or exceed targets. Companies like Salesforce have seen improved performance when employees are rewarded with bonuses, which can lead to increased overall profitability.On the other hand, relying solely on financial rewards can have negative consequences. When only a select few receive these rewards, it can create resentment and a sense of unfairness among those who feel overlooked. This can undermine teamwork, as employees focus more on individual success rather than collaborative achievement. Moreover, relying on financial incentives can erode intrinsic motivation, as employees who are initially driven by passion may become more focused on financial gain, leading to burnout or disengagement if rewards are not consistently met.To create a more inclusive and sustainable workplace motivation, companies could consider alternative recognition strategies that go beyond financial rewards. Options such as opportunities for professional growth, flexible work arrangements, and public recognition of achievements can foster a culture of appreciation and gratitude. For instance, Google's emphasis on employee engagement through its open culture and innovation-friendly policies helps maintain high morale and performance without relying solely on financial incentives.In conclusion, while financial rewards can be an effective motivator, they are not without drawbacks. A more balanced approach that combines both financial and non-financial strategies is more likely to create a harmonious and motivated workplace, ultimately leading to greater employee satisfaction and company success.

question: Present a written argument or case to an educated non-specialist audience on the following topic:Under British and Australian laws a jury in a criminal case has no access to information about the defendant's past criminal record. This protects the person who is being accused of the crime.Some lawyers have suggested that this practice should be changed and that a jury should be given all the past facts before they reach their decision about the case.Do you agree or disagree?Give reasons for your answer and include any relevant examples from your own knowledge or experience.
human: In the UK and Australia, a jury is not provided with the defendant's previous criminal history. Some law representatives claim that this should be reverted, and the jury must be provided with this information beforehand. I fully agree with this statement since the jury will have a better understanding of the defendant's behaviour, and the final decision will be easier to understand for the audience.Having the jury the right access to the defendant's past criminal background, would provide the jury with enough information about the defendant's behaviour. This is because there are certain previous criminal behavioural patterns which allow a better profesional decision-making from the part of the jury. For example, a recent study of the Law's Practice of Melboune, has shown that around 77% of people who commit a crime, were involved in at least one criminal event in the past with similar characteristics to the current crime.On the other hand, if the jury has access to the defendant's past criminal history, it would be easier for the audience to understand the nature of the jury's final decision. This is because there have been cases in which the jury's final decision was not completely accepted by the audience or misunderstood. Therefore, providing the jury with enough criminal backgroud records of the defendant will make it clear to understand in beased of what or why the jury's final decision was made.In conclusion, in the UK and Australia, a jury does not have access to a defendant's previous criminal records, and some law representatives claim that this should be reverted. I fully agree with this statement since being provided with this documents will allow the jury a more understanding of the defendant's behaviour, and the final jury's decision will be easier to understand for the audience.
llm: The principle of withholding a defendant's past criminal record from a jury in a criminal trial is based on the fundamental goal of ensuring a fair and impartial trial. This practice, commonly followed in British and Australian law, aims to shield the defendant from potential biases that may arise from information unrelated to the current case.The primary concern is that introducing a defendant's past criminal record can unfairly influence the jury's perception of the accused. Human nature tends to make judgments based on prior behavior, which may lead jurors to assume that a person with a criminal history is more likely to commit further crimes, regardless of the specifics of the current charges. This bias undermines the core principle of justice, which presumes that every individual is innocent until proven guilty.Furthermore, a defendant's past crimes may not be relevant to the case at trial. Each case should be evaluated based on its unique circumstances, rather than assumptions drawn from past behavior. For instance, consider a person who committed a minor offense decades ago and has since led a law-abiding life. Exposing the jury to that past could unfairly influence their deliberation about a completely different and unrelated accusation.Some argue that including past records can provide context, but the risk of prejudice outweighs any potential benefits. Legal systems worldwide strive for fairness, and allowing juries access to a defendant's criminal history contradicts this principle, potentially leading to wrongful convictions.In conclusion, I strongly believe that juries should not have access to a defendant's past criminal record. Upholding the integrity of a fair trial and protecting individual rights are crucial in maintaining a just legal system. By ensuring that juries focus solely on the evidence pertinent to the case at hand, we can promote a more equitable judicial process.

question: Professional sportsmen and sportswomen and professional entertainers can often command enormous salaries today and this situation reflects society’s dependence on being entertained.To what extent do you agree or disagree with this?Give reasons for your answer and include any relevant examples from your knowledge or experience.You should write at least 250 words.
human: It is no secret that today’s entertainment industry is extremely popular, with nearly everyone being engaged at some time in watching TV shows, movies and sports games. The North American sports industry alone generates a massive $67.7 billion every year. With the present emphasis on entertainment, sportsmen and women and professional entertainers can earn enormous salaries, with figures in the millions for one game, appearance or film. This situation certainly does reflect today’s society’s obsession with entertainment.Many people argue that celebrities do not deserve such payment when work in other professions considered of equal or higher value to society is underpaid. A-list celebrities can make over $20 million per movie, whilst many average workers can barely make ends meet. Of course there are lots of people who say that there are better ways the money could be used, rather than allowing such a vast amount to go to just one person. This is a fairly naive point of view, though. So long as people wish to watch entertainment, advertising in turn will be present and the most watched celebrities will be able to earn high salaries, as their presence will ensure the high viewing figures the advertisers desire.Though celebrities and sportsmen and sportswomen often make very large sums of money, it can also be seen as unfair to say that they do not deserve it or propose their money be used for something else. While it is true that they did not find a cure for cancer or made a life-changing scientific discovery, their hard work and expertise created a product that the public wants to see and the high payment merely reflects their value.In conclusion, it is clear that today’s society is indeed a society obsessed with being entertained and the high salaries paid to those who entertain society clearly reflect this. The high payments, however, are not necessarily out of place or undeserved.
llm: The significant salaries earned by professional athletes and entertainers in today's society are a clear indication of our cultural dependence on entertainment. This statement is largely accurate, as it highlights the economic influence of the entertainment industry and the increasing demand for leisure activities in modern life.The massive global following of sports and entertainment is a key factor in their importance in our daily lives. Major events such as the Super Bowl and the FIFA World Cup draw in millions of viewers worldwide, resulting in substantial revenue from broadcasting rights, sponsorships, and merchandise sales. It is reasonable that top athletes and entertainers receive a considerable share of the profits they help generate. For instance, high-profile athletes like Lionel Messi and LeBron James showcase their exceptional talents while also playing a crucial role in the economic systems that contribute significantly to national and global economies.Moreover, people are increasingly seeking escapism from the pressures of daily life. As work-life balance becomes more valued, individuals are turning to sports and entertainment as a means of relaxation and enjoyment. This is evident in the willingness of consumers to spend large amounts on tickets, merchandise, and streaming services, which in turn inflates the salaries of those providing the entertainment.However, it is essential to acknowledge the disparity in compensation across different professions. Educators and healthcare professionals, for example, often receive relatively modest salaries despite their vital roles in society. This raises questions about societal priorities and the value placed on entertainment compared to essential services.In conclusion, the substantial salaries of professional athletes and entertainers indeed reflect society's reliance on entertainment. While their contributions to economic growth are undeniable, it also emphasizes the need for a broader discussion about societal values and the true worth of various professions in our communities.

question: Providing a national system in a country where the unemployed receive a regular payment only encourages people not to seek work and puts an unreasonable strain on a country’s financial resources.Discuss this statement and give your opinion.Give reasons for your answer and include any relevant examples from your knowledge or experience.You should write at least 250 words.
human: In modern day society, money is a driving force for nearly everyone. Most people aspire to be financially secure and to have the ability to live the life they want. However, not everyone is able to find paid employment, and for that reason in some countries around the world, governments have initiated a system where the unemployed receive a regular payment to enable them to survive. Some people believe it is an excellent idea, whilst others believe that it is exhausting a country’s financial resources.When looking at the positive aspects of this system, it can be said that it prevents individuals from having a private bankruptcy. When somebody becomes unemployed, he or she will have on-going costs such as rent for a dwelling, bills for water, telephone and electricity as well as the cost of food and several other things. Without a salary, this person will fall into debt, because they will be unable to cover these expenses. A national unemployment payment system will therefore prevent this person from losing nearly everything over time. Without such system, many people would become homeless and would potentially engage in criminal activities to survive. Therefore, one can say that this system is positive. Although stories are heard of people exploiting the system, usually the newly unemployed want to find a job fast in order to become financially independent again, meaning that the government does not have to support them for long.Although there are positive aspects of this system, one can also say that if the payment made by the government is too high, it will prevent people from looking for work actively. Occasionally, the payment people receive is higher than their potential salaries, deterring them from working and creating an on-going cost for the government. A potential solution for this could be providing free training and employment support to open up new career opportunities with higher income, which would motivate this group to re-enter the workforce.In conclusion, the unemployment benefits system has positive and negative aspects. Personally, I believe that the positive effects of the system outweigh the negative. The payment must remain on a level that helps people survive without regular salaries, but does not seem attractive to exploit over a longer period of time.
llm: The establishment of a national system to provide regular financial assistance to the unemployed has sparked intense debate. Advocates believe that this system is crucial in supporting individuals who are out of work, while opponents argue that it may unintentionally discourage people from seeking employment and put a strain on the nation's financial resources.Those who oppose unemployment benefits often claim that they can create a reliance on government support. When individuals receive regular payments, they may become less motivated to find work, as they may believe they can maintain their livelihood through government assistance. This phenomenon, often referred to as the "welfare trap," could potentially lead to a decrease in the number of people participating in the labor force, which would hinder economic growth and innovation. For example, if individuals can meet their basic needs through these payments, their desire to actively seek job opportunities may decrease.Furthermore, the financial implications of a national unemployment system are significant and cannot be ignored. Implementing such a system often requires substantial government expenditure, which can lead to budget deficits and the reallocation of resources from essential services. Countries with high unemployment rates may face severe fiscal challenges, forcing them to either increase taxes or reduce spending in other areas. The case of Greece during the economic crisis is a prime example, where extensive unemployment benefits contributed to a fiscal imbalance, ultimately requiring austerity measures that affected the entire population.However, it is crucial to balance these criticisms with examples of successful unemployment systems that provide benefits without discouraging work. Programs that combine financial support with job training and placement services, such as those implemented in Scandinavian countries, demonstrate that it is possible to support the unemployed while also encouraging them to re-enter the workforce.In conclusion, while the concerns about unemployment benefits potentially discouraging job seeking and straining fiscal resources are legitimate, the approach to implementing such systems is vital. A well-designed unemployment support system that incorporates incentives for employment and skill development can mitigate these issues and have a positive impact on both individuals and society as a whole.

question: Public health is becoming an urgent issue nowadays. Some argue that governments should create nutrition and food choice laws to improve public health, while others believe that it is a matter of personal choice and responsibility. Discuss both views and give your opinion.
human: Public health has become an increasingly pressing issue in the modern world, with many populations facing rising rates of obesity, diabetes, and other diet-related diseases. This has led to a debate as to whether governments should establish nutrition and food choice laws for the betterment of public health or if it solely falls on individuals to make wise choices. In my view, everyone should take ownership of their diet and assume responsibility for their health because it is the right choice.The argument for government-imposed nutrition and food choice laws is that they could help prevent people from making unhealthy choices which could lead to more serious illnesses down the line. For example, government regulations could limit the amount of sugar or fats allowed in food products, especially those marketed to children, and impose taxes on unhealthy snacks like chips and candy bars. This approach would also benefit those who lack the knowledge about healthy food, necessary to make informed decisions. By providing clear guidelines on what foods are healthy, and by taxing the unhealthy options higher, the government would steer individuals away from unhealthy options.However, there are also some valid arguments against governmental intervention. These types of regulations infringe upon individuals’ right to choose what they put in their bodies. After all, everyone should be free to make lifestyle choices for themselves. Additionally, there may not be enough evidence to suggest that overly restrictive regulations would have beneficial effects on public health outcomes in the long run. Since people’s love of unhealthy food is often considered an addiction, it is unlikely that a higher price or other warnings would be enough to deter individuals from purchasing unhealthy food items.In conclusion, while there can certainly be benefits associated with implementing nutrition and food choice laws at a governmental level, ultimately it should still come down to personal choice and responsibility as far as one’s diet is concerned. Governments should instead focus on providing citizens with better nutrition education, so that they can make better informed decisions about what they consume. This way, they can receive the information they need while still having autonomy over their own diets and lifestyles.
llm: The increasing prevalence of lifestyle-related diseases, obesity, and chronic health conditions has made public health a major concern in today's society. As a result, a debate has emerged about whether governments should play a role in regulating nutrition and food choices to improve public health, or if this should remain the sole responsibility of individuals.Those in favor of government intervention believe that public health is a collective issue that requires a unified approach. They argue that many people lack the necessary knowledge or resources to make informed decisions about their diet, and that the food industry's marketing tactics often encourage unhealthy choices. To combat this, they propose regulations such as mandatory labeling, limits on sugar and salt in processed foods, and restrictions on advertising unhealthy products to children. By enacting these laws, governments can create an environment that encourages healthier choices and reduces the financial burden of diet-related illnesses on the healthcare system.On the other hand, those opposed to such regulations argue that individuals should have the freedom to make their own dietary choices without government interference. They believe that people are capable of making informed decisions about their food choices and that giving the government control over nutrition could lead to an overreach of power and a loss of personal autonomy. Instead, they advocate for education and awareness campaigns to promote healthy eating as a personal choice rather than a government-imposed requirement.In my view, while personal responsibility is crucial, the government also has a vital role to play in shaping public health policy. A balanced approach that combines education and regulation can effectively address public health concerns. By implementing laws that promote healthier food environments and providing educational resources, the government can empower individuals to make better choices while supporting the well-being of communities. Ultimately, public health is a shared responsibility that requires cooperation between individuals, the health sector, and policymakers to ensure the well-being of populations.

question: Reporting of crimes and other kinds of violent news on television and in newspapers can have adverse consquences. This kind of information should be restricted from being shown in the media. To what extent do you agree or disagree with this statement?
human: Reporting violent crimes and other violent issues could represents a adverse consequence sometimes. Overall, it is important to enphasyded that people are geting more and more violant and we can't blame only media as a mainly factor for those behavior.This kind of questions is almost a phylosical one and we will keeping this doubt for a long time, or even never now if people are becoming more agressive because they are more expousure to this kind of news, or if we are having more report regarding to violence just because people are getting more violent.I believe that people could feel estimulated to be a criminous person when they have a minimium certain that they won't be punish.For instance, stolen and other minimius crimes had increase at california region after they anounced that stolen under tham $1000 are consider a crime anymore. So the sensation that people could do anything wrong and that is no penalty for that, estimulates the number for stolen.In other hand, when we see some hardly rules the number of crime are dipest low, as we can see at Dubai, for instance. As all penalties are really hard and strongly implemented this place is considering highest safe.I bilieve that restricting any kind of information be showen in the media doesn't solve the problem, and, in fact, bring another new problem related to limited population information. llm: The media's coverage of crime and violence has been a long-standing point of contention, sparking debates about its influence on society. Although it is indisputable that such reporting keeps the public informed about community risks and events, I contend that the unregulated dissemination of violent news can have deleterious consequences, necessitating some form of restriction.Primarily, the relentless exposure to violent news can desensitize audiences, leading to a diminished capacity for empathy towards victims and a distorted perception of violence prevalence in society. For example, frequent exposure to graphic content may lead individuals to perceive violence as a societal norm, resulting in heightened anxiety and fear that can negatively impact mental health.Furthermore, the sensationalized reporting of crimes can perpetuate a cycle of violence, often referred to as the "copycat effect." This phenomenon suggests that exposure to detailed accounts of violent acts can inspire similar behavior in susceptible individuals, providing a potential blueprint for future incidents. Consequently, seemingly harmless news items can inadvertently provoke further aggression rather than educate or inform the public.Additionally, the media's preoccupation with violent news often overshadows other significant stories, creating a skewed representation of reality. Positive community initiatives, social justice advancements, and acts of kindness are frequently eclipsed by crime reports, fostering a pessimistic outlook on society. This distorted perspective can have far-reaching consequences, contributing to a negative and inaccurate perception of societal norms.In conclusion, while the media plays a vital role in keeping the public informed, the unregulated reporting of crime and violence can have severe consequences. Responsible journalism should strive to strike a balance between transparency and the potential psychological impacts on the audience. Therefore, implementing some level of restriction or moderation in the reporting of violent news may be essential to safeguard societal well-being and promote a more informed and empathetic public.

question: Rich countries often give money to poorer countries, but it does not solve poverty. Therefore, developed countries should give other types of help to the poor countries rather than financial aid. To what extent do you agree or disagree?
human: Poverty represents a worldwide crisis. It is the ugliest epidemic in a region, which could infect countries in the most debilitating ways. To tackle this issue, rich countries need to help those in need and give a hand when possible. I agree that there are several ways of aiding poor countries other than financial aid, like providing countries in need with engineers, workers, and soldiers who would build infrastructure. Building universities, hospitals, and roadways. By having a solid infrastructure, poor countries would be able to monetise their profits and build a stronger and more profitable economy which would help them in the long term. Once unprivilged countries find their niche, the major hurdle would be passed and would definitely pave the way for much brighter future. However, I do disagree that financial aid does not solve poverty, it does if used properly and efficiently. The most determining factor if financial aid would be the way to go, is by identifying what type of poor countries' representative are dealing with. Some countries will have a responsible leader and some will not, with that being said, implementing a strategy, to distinguish responsible leaders from others, would tailor the type of aid rich countries could use. An example, A clear report and constant observation would be applied to track the progress and how this type of aid is being monetized. In summary, types of aid varies from country to another, and tailoring the type of aid is of paramount importance to solve this problem that had huge toll on poor countries.
llm: The ongoing struggle with poverty in developing countries has led wealthy nations to offer financial aid in an effort to alleviate economic difficulties. Nevertheless, the effectiveness of this aid has been a topic of extensive debate, with many arguing that alternative forms of support could be more beneficial.A significant reason why financial assistance often fails to eradicate poverty is the corruption and mismanagement that frequently accompanies these funds. Often, the money meant to improve communities is diverted by corrupt officials or improperly allocated to ineffective projects, resulting in the most vulnerable populations not receiving any real benefits. This diminishes the potential impact of financial aid, casting doubt on its effectiveness as a sole solution.On the other hand, providing assistance in the form of education, technology transfer, or capacity building may lead to more lasting results. For example, investing in education gives individuals the skills and knowledge they need to pursue better job opportunities and ultimately escape poverty. Similarly, technological assistance can improve agricultural production, enhance healthcare services, and encourage entrepreneurship, thereby promoting economic independence.Furthermore, developed countries could focus on creating trade partnerships and promoting equitable trade practices, allowing less wealthy nations to access global markets on fair terms. Such measures would not only boost local economies but also create employment opportunities and encourage entrepreneurial ventures.Although financial aid may still have a role in emergency situations, the complexities of poverty require a more comprehensive approach. By prioritizing education, technology, and trade, wealthy countries can promote long-term development rather than providing temporary solutions. In conclusion, while acknowledging that financial assistance can provide immediate relief, I firmly believe that it should be supplemented with other forms of aid to effectively combat poverty in developing nations.

question: Schools should select students by their academic abilities, agree or disagree?
human: Some people think that schools should select students according to their academic abilities, while others believe that it is better to have students with different abilities studying together. Discuss both views and state your own opinion.Some people contend that mixed ability classes are more beneficial for children’s development than streaming them on the basis of judgement about their academic abilities. However, from my perspective, I disagree with this contention.Admittedly, mixed ability classes provide a better environment for children’s all-round development. In such classes, children with different abilities study together and in turn they can learn from one another. From example, a student, who is good at academic study but weak in dancing or painting, can learn how to dance or paint his peers. In this sense, mixed ability classes allow students to develop their abilities in different subjects instead of only academic abilities.Despite the argument above, I believe streaming students brings more benefits to teachers and students. As for teachers, separating children with better academic abilities from others facilitates effective teaching. This practice helps teachers to control their students more conveniently and easily. Compared with mixed ability in which teacher should consider students’ differences when they are using teaching methodologies, streaming makes this situation simpler. To be more specific, students are at the same level of academic ability in a class, and in turn teachers can use the same methodologies for them all. In this way, the narrower the spread of ability in the class, the more convenient the teaching can be.On top of this, enables students to learn in an effective way. According to students’ different abilities, they are taught in different ways that are more suitable for them. In the top streams, students use more difficult materials, therefore, they can learn more. In sharp contrast, teachers can explain the material more slowly to those in bottom streams. Under this circumstance, students with different academic abilities can study effectively and efficiently.In the final analysis, mixed ability classes are beneficial for students’ versatile development, but in my opinion, segregating students based on different academic ability is better for both teachers and students.The writer presented a balanced discussion of the topic, effortlessly delivered in a form of a fluent, well-written IELTS essay. The arguments and reasoning are laid out in a coherent, logical way. A wide range of vocabulary is used in this work. There are very few spelling errors that could have been caught in an additional round of proofreading (mouse over the words underlined in blue shows corrections). Keep up the good work! Overall, this essay seems worthy of IELTS Band 8.
llm: The discussion about whether schools should admit students based on their academic capabilities has been a longstanding issue in education policy debates. Although there are valid arguments on both sides, I strongly believe that academic ability should be a crucial factor in the student selection process.The main argument in favor of this approach is that it encourages a merit-based system. By choosing students based on their academic achievements, schools can ensure that the most capable students are given the chance to excel in a challenging academic setting. This can result in a more motivated and engaged student body, which in turn promotes a culture of high academic standards. When students with a natural aptitude for academics are surrounded by like-minded peers, it can enhance collaborative learning and intellectual growth.Additionally, selecting students based on academic ability allows schools to tailor their curriculum and resources to meet the specific needs of their student population. This enables schools to create advanced programs for gifted students and provide extra support for those who need it, resulting in a more effective learning experience for all students. By allocating resources based on specific needs, schools can move away from a one-size-fits-all approach and towards a more personalized education.However, it's essential to note that academic ability should not be the only consideration for admission. Other essential qualities like creativity, leadership skills, and emotional intelligence are vital for a well-rounded education. Nevertheless, I argue that placing a strong emphasis on academic ability can lead to a more productive and dynamic learning environment.In summary, while the selection process should take into account a range of attributes, prioritizing academic ability enables schools to foster a dedicated and high-achieving student population. Ultimately, this can lead to more successful outcomes for both students and the educational institutions they attend, creating a positive and supportive learning environment that promotes academic excellence.

question: Scientists believe that the world is in danger due to environmental changes. Some people say that personal lifestyle changes should be made to reduce the damage to environment, while others think that the government should do something to help. Discuss both views and give your own opinion.
human: Environmental problems are clearly something that is often discussed in today’s world. One part of the society claims that individuals should change their habits and lifestyle to improve the ecological situation. Others, on the other hand, believe that this issue should be solved on the governmental level. This essay will discuss both sides of the argument and my perspective will be offered.It is hard to deny that human kind is responsible for the current environmental situation, and it seems impossible to achieve any noticeable result in this field without the participation of vast majority of individuals. For instance, a simple lifestyle change such as introducing the separation of household rubbish can make recycling projects more convenient and efficient. Moreover, consumers can reduce their usage of plastic items and, in turn, less plastic waste will contaminate the environment.However, many people still feel that the government has more tools to prevent environmental changes. One option that the authorities have is to discourage citizens from using personal vehicles by charging high taxes and additional fees. Moreover, politicians usually have access to resources to educate people about environmental problems and promote the most important ecological projects on all levels, ranging from special courses at schools to TV shows and websites related to this topic. Furthermore, it is a key responsibility of the government to protect the environment by spending state funds on research and modern equipment. Countries where legislation protects the ecology, for example Norway, have achieved visible results and overcame most environmental problems.In conclusion, I believe that a combined approach will work best to prevent or reverse environmental changes. A contribution of every individual is just as important as the intervention from the government in order to fix existing issues and save our planet for future generations.
llm: The discussion around environmental degradation often focuses on the parts individuals and governments play in addressing the issue. Some people believe that personal lifestyle changes can collectively make a significant difference in improving environmental health. They argue that simple changes, such as reducing waste, choosing sustainable products, and eating a plant-based diet, can help reduce carbon footprints. By making conscious choices, individuals can not only improve their own well-being but also contribute to a broader cultural shift towards sustainability. Supporting local eco-friendly businesses and participating in community initiatives can create a positive impact that inspires others to do the same.Others, however, believe that governments should take the lead in tackling environmental problems. They argue that governments have the power to create systemic changes through legislation, regulations, and policies, which can have a much greater impact than individual actions alone. For example, governments can enforce emission regulations, invest in renewable energy, and promote sustainable infrastructure. The scale of environmental challenges, such as climate change and pollution, requires a comprehensive approach that can only be achieved through coordinated government efforts. Furthermore, government policies can encourage businesses to adopt sustainable practices by supporting innovative technologies, which can amplify the positive impact on the environment.In my view, a combination of individual actions and government policies is necessary to effectively address environmental challenges. While personal initiatives can raise awareness and promote responsible behavior, government intervention is crucial for large-scale changes that can shape our economic and social systems. Only through a partnership between individuals and authorities can we create a sustainable path that mitigates environmental damage and preserves the planet for future generations. By adopting both approaches, we can develop a multifaceted response that can effectively tackle the complexities of environmental change.

question: Senior managers should have higher salaries than other employees (agree/disagree)
human: In many countries senior positions have higher salaries compared to those of young workers of the same company. Some people think this isn’t justified. Do you agree or disagree?While some believe that rewarding those in managerial positions with higher pay packets is appropriate, not everyone agrees with this view. Personally, I am leaning towards the latter position due to negative impacts caused by significant difference in salaries within a company.For one, executive officers should know that higher than sufficient salaries are not necessary. Indeed, the higher the remuneration they receive, the more likely the company to suffer from devoid of financial capability. Furthermore, they often gain powers that money can’t buy. For instance, they often make important decisions over how to make their company thrive. They are also entitled to allocate company’s budget and designate tasks to other workers. these non-financial entitlements, they should refrain from earning more than reasonable amounts as salaries.Unreasonably high salaries granted to the executives can also afflict other employees. In fact, it is foreseeable that many employees would feel powerless or even when they find out about the huge salary gap between the executive officers’ and theirs. Accordingly, some may leave the company, and others may go on to strike and demand a pay increase. However, those actions . Therefore, unfair salary systems like this would yield unhealthy working environment for both employers and employees.In conclusion, I oppose to those in managerial roles with obscene amounts of compensation because it can cost the company its prosperity and discourage other employees . Thus it is recommended for the company to decide on the salaries of executive officers and general workers by adopting a more motivating salary system.This is a good example of an IELTS Band 8 essay. The task statement is sufficiently discussed, and the writer’s arguments are relevant and well developed. There are only 2 body paragraphs, but they are coherent and help to organise the information. Linking words are used appropriately to sequence ideas. Skillful use of synonyms throughout the essay demonstrates the writer’s vocabulary. Some of the expressions used aren’t entirely suitable or accurate, but there aren’t many of them. Overall, this essay seems worthy of IELTS Band 8.0.
llm: The discussion about whether senior managers should earn higher salaries than other employees is complex and requires thoughtful consideration. In my opinion, senior managers should indeed receive higher salaries than their colleagues, and this viewpoint is based on three primary considerations: the role's responsibilities, the necessary skills, and the impact on the organization's performance.To begin with, senior managers bear significant responsibilities that directly influence the company's direction and success. They make critical decisions that can lead to increased profits or even the company's downfall. Their duties often involve leading large teams, managing budgets, and maintaining stakeholder relationships, which demands a high level of expertise and leadership. Given the far-reaching consequences of their decisions, higher compensation is justified as it acknowledges the weight of their responsibilities.Furthermore, the skill sets required for senior management positions are typically extensive and unique. Senior managers often possess years of experience, advanced degrees, or specialized training that are not commonly found in other employees. Their ability to navigate complex business environments, anticipate market trends, and develop strategic plans requires a high level of intellectual and emotional intelligence. A salary that reflects these advanced skill sets can also motivate current employees to strive for senior positions, fostering a culture of ambition and growth within the organization.Lastly, competitive salaries for senior managers can have a positive impact on the organization's performance. Attractive compensation packages enable companies to attract and retain top talent, ultimately benefiting the entire organization. Effective leadership is essential for inspiring employees and driving productivity, and well-compensated senior managers are more motivated to perform at their best, benefiting the organization as a whole.In conclusion, the case for higher salaries for senior managers is compelling, considering their critical responsibilities, unique skills, and positive effects on the company's overall success. Although addressing income inequality is important, the distinct role of senior managers justifies a compensation structure that reflects their vital contributions to the organization.

question: Should employers pay more attention to personal qualities rather than qualifications?
human: While recruiting a new employee, the employer should pay more attention to their personal qualities, rather than qualifications and experience. To what extent do you agree or disagree? Give your opinion and include relevant examples.Recent decades have witnessed a burgeoning growth of numerous industries; therefore, recruiting the right person for the position is crucial to the development of enterprises. But how do we determine if a person is the best fit? Advocates of conventional recruitment methods opine that this candidate must have sufficient experience and qualifications needed for that job. Nevertheless, some people argue that candidates’ personal qualities cannot be ignored. In my view, both components are of equal importance.To begin with, the conventional approach of checking potential workers’ qualifications via their resumes, LinkedIn profiles, issued qualifications and certifications from authorised organisations is vital. Apparently, whenever we submit a job application, we are always required to attach a CV while a cover letter is optional.
